trans-unit.source: How to use blob storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use blob storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Blob service to upload, download, list, and delete blob content.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Blob service to upload, download, list, and delete blob content.

trans-unit.source: Samples written in Node.js.
trans-unit.target: Samples written in Node.js.

trans-unit.source: How to use blob storage from Node.js
trans-unit.target: How to use blob storage from Node.js

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Blob service.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Azure Blob service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written using the Node.js API.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written using the Node.js API.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include **uploading**, **listing**, **downloading**, and **deleting** blobs.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include **uploading**, **listing**, **downloading**, and **deleting** blobs.

trans-unit.source: Create a Node.js application
trans-unit.target: Create a Node.js application

trans-unit.source: Create a blank Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: Create a blank Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure web site], [Node.js Cloud Service][Node.js Cloud Service] (using Windows PowerShell), or [Web Site with WebMatrix].
trans-unit.target: For instructions creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure web site], [Node.js Cloud Service][Node.js Cloud Service] (using Windows PowerShell), or [Web Site with WebMatrix].

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to access storage
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to access storage

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use Node Package Manager (NPM) to obtain the package
trans-unit.target: Use Node Package Manager (NPM) to obtain the package

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as **PowerShell** (Windows), **Terminal** (Mac), or **Bash** (Unix), to navigate to the folder where you created your sample application.
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as **PowerShell** (Windows), **Terminal** (Mac), or **Bash** (Unix), to navigate to the folder where you created your sample application.

trans-unit.source: Type **npm install azure-storage** in the command window.
trans-unit.target: Type **npm install azure-storage** in the command window.

trans-unit.source: Output from the command is similar to the following code example.
trans-unit.target: Output from the command is similar to the following code example.

trans-unit.source: You can manually run the **ls** command to verify that a **node\_modules** folder was created.
trans-unit.target: You can manually run the **ls** command to verify that a **node\_modules** folder was created.

trans-unit.source: Inside that folder find the **azure-storage** package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.
trans-unit.target: Inside that folder find the **azure-storage** package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.

trans-unit.source: Import the package
trans-unit.target: Import the package

trans-unit.source: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top the
trans-unit.target: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top the

trans-unit.source: **server.js** file of the application where you intend to use storage:
trans-unit.target: **server.js** file of the application where you intend to use storage:

trans-unit.source: Set up an Azure Storage connection
trans-unit.target: Set up an Azure Storage connection

trans-unit.source: The Azure module will read the environment variables `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT` and `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY`, or `AZURE_STORAGE_CONNECTION_STRING` for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The Azure module will read the environment variables `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCOUNT` and `AZURE_STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY`, or `AZURE_STORAGE_CONNECTION_STRING` for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling **createBlobService**.
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling **createBlobService**.

trans-unit.source: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]
trans-unit.target: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]

trans-unit.source: Create a container
trans-unit.target: Create a container

trans-unit.source: The **BlobService** object lets you work with containers and blobs.
trans-unit.target: The **BlobService** object lets you work with containers and blobs.

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a **BlobService** object.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a **BlobService** object.

trans-unit.source: Add the following near the top of **server.js**:
trans-unit.target: Add the following near the top of **server.js**:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can access a blob anonymously by using **createBlobServiceAnonymous** and providing the host address.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can access a blob anonymously by using **createBlobServiceAnonymous** and providing the host address.

trans-unit.source: For example, `var blobSvc = azure.createBlobServiceAnonymous('https://myblob.blob.core.windows.net/');`.
trans-unit.target: For example, `var blobSvc = azure.createBlobServiceAnonymous('https://myblob.blob.core.windows.net/');`.

trans-unit.source: To create a new container, use **createContainerIfNotExists**.
trans-unit.target: To create a new container, use **createContainerIfNotExists**.

trans-unit.source: The following code example creates a new container named 'mycontainer'
trans-unit.target: The following code example creates a new container named 'mycontainer'

trans-unit.source: If the container is newly created, `result` is true.
trans-unit.target: If the container is newly created, `result` is true.

trans-unit.source: If the container already exists, `result` is false.
trans-unit.target: If the container already exists, `result` is false.

trans-unit.source: `response` contains information about the operation, including the [ETag](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_ETag) information for the container.
trans-unit.target: `response` contains information about the operation, including the [ETag](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_ETag) information for the container.

trans-unit.source: Container security
trans-unit.target: Container security

trans-unit.source: By default, new containers are private and cannot be accessed anonymously.
trans-unit.target: By default, new containers are private and cannot be accessed anonymously.

trans-unit.source: To make the container public so that you can access them anonymously, you can set the container's access level to **blob** or **container**.
trans-unit.target: To make the container public so that you can access them anonymously, you can set the container's access level to **blob** or **container**.

trans-unit.source: **blob** - allows anonymous read access to blob content and metadata within this container, but not to container metadata such as listing all blobs within a container
trans-unit.target: **blob** - allows anonymous read access to blob content and metadata within this container, but not to container metadata such as listing all blobs within a container

trans-unit.source: **container** - allows anonymous read access to blob content and metadata as well as container metadata
trans-unit.target: **container** - allows anonymous read access to blob content and metadata as well as container metadata

trans-unit.source: The following code example demonstrates setting the access level to **blob**:
trans-unit.target: The following code example demonstrates setting the access level to **blob**:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can modify the access level of a container by using **setContainerAcl** to specify the access level.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can modify the access level of a container by using **setContainerAcl** to specify the access level.

trans-unit.source: The following code example changes the access level to container:
trans-unit.target: The following code example changes the access level to container:

trans-unit.source: The result contains information about the operation, including the current **ETag** for the container.
trans-unit.target: The result contains information about the operation, including the current **ETag** for the container.

trans-unit.source: Filters
trans-unit.target: Filters

trans-unit.source: You can apply optional filtering operations to operations performed using **BlobService**.
trans-unit.target: You can apply optional filtering operations to operations performed using **BlobService**.

trans-unit.source: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:
trans-unit.target: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:

trans-unit.source: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:
trans-unit.target: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:

trans-unit.source: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback to end the service invocation.
trans-unit.target: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback to end the service invocation.

trans-unit.source: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, **ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter** and **LinearRetryPolicyFilter**.
trans-unit.target: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, **ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter** and **LinearRetryPolicyFilter**.

trans-unit.source: The following creates a **BlobService** object that uses the **ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter**:
trans-unit.target: The following creates a **BlobService** object that uses the **ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter**:

trans-unit.source: Upload a blob into a container
trans-unit.target: Upload a blob into a container

trans-unit.source: A blob can be either block or page based.
trans-unit.target: A blob can be either block or page based.

trans-unit.source: Block blobs allow you to more efficiently upload large data, while page blobs are optimized for read/write operations.
trans-unit.target: Block blobs allow you to more efficiently upload large data, while page blobs are optimized for read/write operations.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Understanding block blobs and page blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Understanding block blobs and page blobs](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee691964.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Block blobs
trans-unit.target: Block blobs

trans-unit.source: To upload data to a block blob, use the following:
trans-unit.target: To upload data to a block blob, use the following:

trans-unit.source: **createBlockBlobFromLocalFile** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a file
trans-unit.target: **createBlockBlobFromLocalFile** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a file

trans-unit.source: **createBlockBlobFromStream** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a stream
trans-unit.target: **createBlockBlobFromStream** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a stream

trans-unit.source: **createBlockBlobFromText** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a string
trans-unit.target: **createBlockBlobFromText** - creates a new block blob and uploads the contents of a string

trans-unit.source: **createWriteStreamToBlockBlob** - provides a write stream to a block blob
trans-unit.target: **createWriteStreamToBlockBlob** - provides a write stream to a block blob

trans-unit.source: The following code example uploads the contents of the **test.txt** file into **myblob**.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uploads the contents of the **test.txt** file into **myblob**.

trans-unit.source: The `result` returned by these methods contains information on the operation, such as the **ETag** of the blob.
trans-unit.target: The `result` returned by these methods contains information on the operation, such as the **ETag** of the blob.

trans-unit.source: Page blobs
trans-unit.target: Page blobs

trans-unit.source: To upload data to a page blob, use the following:
trans-unit.target: To upload data to a page blob, use the following:

trans-unit.source: **createPageBlob** - creates a new page blob of a specific length
trans-unit.target: **createPageBlob** - creates a new page blob of a specific length

trans-unit.source: **createPageBlobFromLocalFile** - creates a new page blob and uploads the contents of a file
trans-unit.target: **createPageBlobFromLocalFile** - creates a new page blob and uploads the contents of a file

trans-unit.source: **createPageBlobFromStream** - creates a new page blob and uploads the contents of a stream
trans-unit.target: **createPageBlobFromStream** - creates a new page blob and uploads the contents of a stream

trans-unit.source: **createWriteStreamToExistingPageBlob** - provides a write stream to an existing page blob
trans-unit.target: **createWriteStreamToExistingPageBlob** - provides a write stream to an existing page blob

trans-unit.source: **createWriteStreamToNewPageBlob** - creates a new blob and then provides a stream to write to it
trans-unit.target: **createWriteStreamToNewPageBlob** - creates a new blob and then provides a stream to write to it

trans-unit.source: The following code example uploads the contents of the **test.txt** file into **mypageblob**.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uploads the contents of the **test.txt** file into **mypageblob**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Page blobs consist of 512-byte 'pages'.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Page blobs consist of 512-byte 'pages'.

trans-unit.source: You may receive an error when uploading data with a size that is not a multiple of 512.
trans-unit.target: You may receive an error when uploading data with a size that is not a multiple of 512.

trans-unit.source: List the blobs in a container
trans-unit.target: List the blobs in a container

trans-unit.source: To list the blobs in a container, use the **listBlobsSegmented** method.
trans-unit.target: To list the blobs in a container, use the **listBlobsSegmented** method.

trans-unit.source: If you would like to return blobs with a specific prefix, use **listBlobsSegmentedWithPrefix**.
trans-unit.target: If you would like to return blobs with a specific prefix, use **listBlobsSegmentedWithPrefix**.

trans-unit.source: The `result` contains an `entries` collection, which is an array of objects describing each blob.
trans-unit.target: The `result` contains an `entries` collection, which is an array of objects describing each blob.

trans-unit.source: If all blobs cannot be returned, the `result` also provides a `continuationToken`, which you may use as the second parameter to retrieve additional entries.
trans-unit.target: If all blobs cannot be returned, the `result` also provides a `continuationToken`, which you may use as the second parameter to retrieve additional entries.

trans-unit.source: Download blobs
trans-unit.target: Download blobs

trans-unit.source: To download data from a blob, use the following:
trans-unit.target: To download data from a blob, use the following:

trans-unit.source: **getBlobToFile** - writes the blob contents to file
trans-unit.target: **getBlobToFile** - writes the blob contents to file

trans-unit.source: **getBlobToStream** - writes the blob contents to a stream
trans-unit.target: **getBlobToStream** - writes the blob contents to a stream

trans-unit.source: **getBlobToText** - writes the blob contents to a string
trans-unit.target: **getBlobToText** - writes the blob contents to a string

trans-unit.source: **createReadStream** - provides a stream to read from the blob
trans-unit.target: **createReadStream** - provides a stream to read from the blob

trans-unit.source: The following code example demonstrates using **getBlobToStream** to download the contents of the **myblob** blob and store it to the **output.txt** file using a stream:
trans-unit.target: The following code example demonstrates using **getBlobToStream** to download the contents of the **myblob** blob and store it to the **output.txt** file using a stream:

trans-unit.source: The `result` contains information about the blob, including **ETag** information.
trans-unit.target: The `result` contains information about the blob, including **ETag** information.

trans-unit.source: Delete a blob
trans-unit.target: Delete a blob

trans-unit.source: Finally, to delete a blob, call **deleteBlob**.
trans-unit.target: Finally, to delete a blob, call **deleteBlob**.

trans-unit.source: The following code example deletes the blob named **myblob**.
trans-unit.target: The following code example deletes the blob named **myblob**.

trans-unit.source: Concurrent access
trans-unit.target: Concurrent access

trans-unit.source: To support concurrent access to a blob from multiple clients or multiple process instances, you can use **ETags** or **leases**.
trans-unit.target: To support concurrent access to a blob from multiple clients or multiple process instances, you can use **ETags** or **leases**.

trans-unit.source: **Etag** - provides a way to detect that the blob or container has been modified by another process
trans-unit.target: **Etag** - provides a way to detect that the blob or container has been modified by another process

trans-unit.source: **Lease** - provides a way to obtain exclusive, renewable, write or delete access to a blob for a period of time
trans-unit.target: **Lease** - provides a way to obtain exclusive, renewable, write or delete access to a blob for a period of time

trans-unit.source: ETag
trans-unit.target: ETag

trans-unit.source: Use ETags if you need to allow multiple clients or instances to write to the blob simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: Use ETags if you need to allow multiple clients or instances to write to the blob simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: The ETag allows you to determine if the container or blob has been modified since you initially read or created it, which allows you to avoid overwriting changes committed by another client or process.
trans-unit.target: The ETag allows you to determine if the container or blob has been modified since you initially read or created it, which allows you to avoid overwriting changes committed by another client or process.

trans-unit.source: You can set ETag conditions by using the optional `options.accessConditions` parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can set ETag conditions by using the optional `options.accessConditions` parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following code example only uploads the **test.txt** file if the blob already exists and has the ETag value contained by `etagToMatch`.
trans-unit.target: The following code example only uploads the **test.txt** file if the blob already exists and has the ETag value contained by `etagToMatch`.

trans-unit.source: The general pattern when using ETags is:
trans-unit.target: The general pattern when using ETags is:

trans-unit.source: Obtain the ETag as the result of a create, list, or get operation.
trans-unit.target: Obtain the ETag as the result of a create, list, or get operation.

trans-unit.source: Perform an action, checking that the ETag value has not been modified.
trans-unit.target: Perform an action, checking that the ETag value has not been modified.

trans-unit.source: If the value has been modified, this indicates that another client or instance has modified the blob or container since you obtained the ETag value.
trans-unit.target: If the value has been modified, this indicates that another client or instance has modified the blob or container since you obtained the ETag value.

trans-unit.source: Lease
trans-unit.target: Lease

trans-unit.source: You can acquire a new lease by using the **acquireLease** method, specifying the blob or container that you wish to obtain a lease on.
trans-unit.target: You can acquire a new lease by using the **acquireLease** method, specifying the blob or container that you wish to obtain a lease on.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following code acquires a lease on **myblob**.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following code acquires a lease on **myblob**.

trans-unit.source: Subsequent operations on **myblob** must provide `options.leaseId` parameter.
trans-unit.target: Subsequent operations on **myblob** must provide `options.leaseId` parameter.

trans-unit.source: The lease ID is returned as `result.id` from **acquireLease**.
trans-unit.target: The lease ID is returned as `result.id` from **acquireLease**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the lease duration is infinite.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the lease duration is infinite.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a non-infinite duration (between 15 and 60 seconds,) by providing the `options.leaseDuration` parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a non-infinite duration (between 15 and 60 seconds,) by providing the `options.leaseDuration` parameter.

trans-unit.source: To remove a lease, use **releaseLease**.
trans-unit.target: To remove a lease, use **releaseLease**.

trans-unit.source: To break a lease, but prevent others from obtaining a new lease until the original duration has expired, use **breakLease**.
trans-unit.target: To break a lease, but prevent others from obtaining a new lease until the original duration has expired, use **breakLease**.

trans-unit.source: Work with shared access signatures
trans-unit.target: Work with shared access signatures

trans-unit.source: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to blobs and containers without providing your storage account name or keys.
trans-unit.target: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to blobs and containers without providing your storage account name or keys.

trans-unit.source: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your data, such as allowing a mobile app to access blobs.
trans-unit.target: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your data, such as allowing a mobile app to access blobs.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] While you can also allow anonymous access to blobs, SAS allows you to provide more controlled access, as you must generate the SAS.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] While you can also allow anonymous access to blobs, SAS allows you to provide more controlled access, as you must generate the SAS.

trans-unit.source: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the **generateSharedAccessSignature** of the **BlobService**, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application such as a mobile app.
trans-unit.target: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the **generateSharedAccessSignature** of the **BlobService**, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application such as a mobile app.

trans-unit.source: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.
trans-unit.target: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.

trans-unit.source: The following code example generates a new shared access policy that allows the SAS holder to perform read operations on the **myblob** blob, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.
trans-unit.target: The following code example generates a new shared access policy that allows the SAS holder to perform read operations on the **myblob** blob, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.

trans-unit.source: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the container.
trans-unit.target: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the container.

trans-unit.source: The client application then uses the SAS with **BlobServiceWithSAS** to perform operations against the blob.
trans-unit.target: The client application then uses the SAS with **BlobServiceWithSAS** to perform operations against the blob.

trans-unit.source: The following gets information about **myblob**.
trans-unit.target: The following gets information about **myblob**.

trans-unit.source: Since the SAS was generated with only read access, if an attempt were made to modify the blob, an error would be returned.
trans-unit.target: Since the SAS was generated with only read access, if an attempt were made to modify the blob, an error would be returned.

trans-unit.source: Access control lists
trans-unit.target: Access control lists

trans-unit.source: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.
trans-unit.target: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.

trans-unit.source: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access a container, but provide different access policies for each client.
trans-unit.target: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access a container, but provide different access policies for each client.

trans-unit.source: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.
trans-unit.target: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.

trans-unit.source: The following code example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':
trans-unit.target: The following code example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':

trans-unit.source: The following code example gets the current ACL for **mycontainer**, then adds the new policies using **setBlobAcl**.
trans-unit.target: The following code example gets the current ACL for **mycontainer**, then adds the new policies using **setBlobAcl**.

trans-unit.source: This approach allows:
trans-unit.target: This approach allows:

trans-unit.source: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.
trans-unit.target: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.

trans-unit.target: The following code example creates a new SAS for 'user2':
